entry.et: Middle English sunne, from Old English; akin to Old High German sunna sun, Latin sol solar

def.dt: :the luminous celestial body around which the earth and other planets revolve, from which they receive heat and light, which is composed mainly of hydrogen and helium, and which has a mean distance from earth of about 93,000,000 miles (150,000,000 kilometers), a linear diameter of 864,000 miles (1,390,000 kilometers), and a mass 332,000 times greater than earth
:the heat or light radiated from the sun played in the sun all day
:one resembling the sun (as in warmth or brilliance)
:the rising or setting of the sun from sun to sun
:to expose to or as if to the rays of the sun
:a small forest-dwelling bear (Ursus malayanus syn. Helarctos malayanus) of southeastern Asia that has short glossy black fur with a lighter muzzle and often an orange or white breast mark
:a solo or group solstice rite of American Indians
:an ancient Near Eastern symbol consisting of a disk with conventionalized wings emblematic of the sun god (as Ra in Egypt)
:a small nearly round halo on the parhelic circle most frequently just outside the halo of 22 degrees
:a god that represents or personifies the sun in various religions
:a goddess that represents or personifies the sun in various religions
:any of a small family (Heliornithidae) of semiaquatic African, Asian, and American tropical birds that have lobed feet and are related to the rails
